head.title: Devils Squander Leads, Not to Mention Confidence

hedline.hl1: Devils Squander Leads, Not to Mention Confidence

block.p: It is perhaps too early to push a panic button or activate a siren, but the Devils' record in the Patrick Division has reached alarming proportions.
A marvelous opportunity to improve their division mark tonight went up in smoke for the Devils in their game against the Islanders at Nassau Coliseum.
It is perhaps too early to push a panic button or activate a siren, but the Devils' record in the Patrick Division has reached alarming proportions.
A marvelous opportunity to improve their division mark tonight went up in smoke for the Devils in their game against the Islanders at Nassau Coliseum.

The Devils had two-goal leads four times against the Islanders, but they allowed two short-handed goals and finally an even-strength goal with 0.5 seconds left in regulation time and settled for a 5-5 deadlock.

Tonight's tie was the 16th Patrick Division game for the Devils and their record in the division is 4-8-4. What is more disheartening is that in the 10 division games outside New Jersey, the Devils have one victory, a 4-2 decision Oct. 24 in Pittsburgh.
"I'm really concerned," Devils Coach Tom McVie said about his team's record in the Patrick Division. "We're not going to get it done with this kind of record in the division."

Jeff Norton and Robert DiMaio scored the short-handed goals, and Derek King got the tying goal for the Islanders with half a second left in the third period. Benoit Hogue and Rich Pilon had the other goals for the Islanders (11-17-6).

Dave Barr had his first and second goals of the season for the Devils (16-13-6), who also had goals from Laurie Boschman, Peter Stastny and Claude Lemieux on a night that only the New Jersey penalty killers had something to be proud of.
That group, which entered the game ranked first in the league, looked every bit as worthy of their ranking in killing a two-man advantage for the Islanders that lasted 37 seconds early in the game.
With help from Chris Terreri's remarkable saves, the Devils killed three penalties in the first period before they opened the scoring on Barr's first goal of the season.
Barr's first goal, a deflection of Aleksei Kasatonov's shot from high in the slot, came with 2 minutes 34 seconds left before the first intermission in a 3-on-1 break for the Devils.
Barr gave the Devils a two-goal cushion with a wrist shot from between the hash marks of the two circles after a pass by Patrik Sudnstrom, 3:36 into the second period.
Norton narrowed the gap for the Islanders with his first goal of the season, 13:50 into the second period, during a power play for the Devils.
Stephane Richer, who was playing the left point on a two-man advantage for the Devils, missed the puck at the Islanders' blue line as one of the Islanders' penalties was expiring.
Norton picked up the puck behind Richer in the neutral zone after he stepped onto the ice from the penalty box and beat Terreri.

Boschman's fifth goal of the season -- but first since Oct. 26 -- gave the Devils a 3-1 lead four minutes later, but Hogue's 15th with 28 seconds left in the period closed the gap again for the Islanders.
A spectacular save by Terreri on Uwe Krup, before the third period was a minute old, kept the Islanders from tying the score and immediately brought a goal at the other end.
Stastny got the quick goal, 66 seconds into the third, for a 4-2 lead, but the Islanders again came within one on Pilon's goal 11:32 into the period.
Lemieux extended the Devils' lead to two goals 24 seconds later before DiMaio's short-handed goal, with 3:25 left, set up King's tying goal on the last tick of the clock in regulation.
"I wanted to make sure I fired it high," King said about his tying goal against Terreri, "because I know he likes to drop."
Terreri said he didn't want to take any risks with the clock running out.
"I knew there was only a couple of seconds left, and I didn't want to go charging out at King," Terreri said. "It was a great shot, it just got underneath the crossbar." HOCKEY
